Award.AwardTitle: Mauka to Makai: Mapping for Sustainable Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
KCC will institute a new STEM multidisciplinary academic Certificate of Achievement in GIS technology. The program will combine hands-on, field experience and observation with applied computer mapping, using local mapping sites to teach skills that can be applied to many different applications. The coursework will incorporate traditional Hawaiian observations for data selection and analysis, along with other information needed for projects on Kaua'i. The courses in this program will be transferrable to four-year institutions.
The intellectual merit of the project comes through offering students a new suite of courses in Geography and Geographical Information Systems (GIS) in an integrated STEM approach that combines traditional teaching methods with digital field data collection and analyses that will be beneficial to the community, while providing the student with a set of skills that are in great demand in the workplace, and in rapidly expanding fields. This group approach, with hands-on projects using local examples for teaching larger principles, incorporates learning directly into community stewardship. The new program brings together many aspects of several STEM courses, while offering visual, spatial and computer tools that support research in a wide range of applications such as mapping oceans, biological resources, agricultural production, charting ocean currents, reef protection, native plant species locations, mapping archeological and cultural sites, cultural access to resources, and others. The broader impacts of the Mauka to Makai Project support a recent State law enacted to restore traditional Hawaiian resource approaches to decision-making and management at the state and local level. The KCC campus and the Niumalu ahupua'a offer a rich teaching environment for integrating STEM studies with other academic areas such as Hawaiian Studies, Botany, Agriculture, Health Sciences and Marine Science. Once established, the program can help support community mapping projects, provide trained GIS specialists, and provide invaluable materials for managing Hawaii's land and oceans from the Native Hawaiian perspective using Western technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Mauka to Makai (from the Mountains to the Sea) project has successfully completed the major goals as outlined in the proposal submitted to NSF-TCUP in 2014. These goals included the curriculum development and program implementation for a community-based mapping and analysis program in Geographic Information System (GIS) technology. The GIS program at Kaua’i Community College (Kaua’i CC) emphasizes teaching and learning from a Native Hawaiian perspective of caring for the land and sea. This GIS program will continue to benefit Kauai CC students by giving students skills that are in high demand in the workplace while combining hands-on field experience with applied GIS, using local mapping sites and Hawaiian examples.

The intellectual merit of the Mauka to Makai: Mapping for Sustainable Learning project can be demonstrated by the successful development and adoption of two separate Certificates of Competence in GIS. The courses integrate a STEM approach that develops skills while also offering a means of incorporating learning directly into community stewardship.

Kaua’i CC GIS students complete place-based semester-long projects that focus on sustainability. Students are encouraged to consider projects that are in their community and have a personal and societal impact. This impact is evidenced by the types projects completed: The Ala Loa, Ke Kahua O Kaneiolouma, Wahi Pana, Accessibility to Local Foods, Kauai Forest Bird Recovery Project, Marine Debris, Botanical Mapping, Monitoring Coral Reef Health, among others.

Digital field data collection takes place alongside traditional teaching methods. Students enrolled in the GIS courses at Kauai CC use smartphones, Garmin GPS devices, as well as survey grade Trimble 7 Geo Series Geocollectors for community benefits such as mapping wahi pana (legendary places). Acquiring high resolution UAS (unmanned aerial systems) imagery of the Botanical Trail at National Tropical Botanical Gardens enabled students to observe predictive modeling for endangered plant locations on Kauai.

The Mauka to Makai project collaborates with many different aspects of STEM courses and clubs (math, sustainability, GoFarm, apiary, engineering, and marine science) while offering the visual, spatial and computer tools to support research in a wide range of applications.

In the three years of offering GIS courses at Kauai CC there have been numerous benefits, including:

  • Project-based learning – student directed projects focuses on authentic geospatial enquiry and develop hands on critical thinking skills
  • Community service –oriented skills based on local sustainability issues such as marine debris, local agriculture and coral reef health monitoring
  • Community outreach –students complete a workshop with visiting keiki (children), and develop training materials that are age appropriate and fun
  • Access to high tech software and field equipment – students have access to the latest versions of ESRI’s ArcGIS Desktop v10.5, ArcGIS Pro, ArcGIS online, Smartphone apps using student created geospatial surveys and field data collection, Garmin GPS Units, and Trimble Geocollectors.
  • Promoting group learning while fostering self – learning skills – field trips and collaborative campus activities encourage leadership.

The broader impacts of the Mauka to Makai project supports traditional Hawaiian resource approaches to decision-making and management at the state and local level.

The GIS program at Kauai CC has helped support several community mapping projects and has provided trained GIS specialists and invaluable materials for managing Hawaii’s land and oceans from the Native Hawaiian perspective. Graduates from the certificate program work for programs such as Kaua’i Invasive Species Committee, Kauai Endangered Sea bird Recovery Project, and Kauai Nene Conservation Program. Community partners and supporters of the GIS program at Kauai CC include the National Tropical Botanical Garden (NTBG), Surfrider Foundation, Kauai Endangered Birds, County of Kauai Planning Department, Kauai Historical Society, Malama Huleia, Ulutopia, and the Kauai Invasive Species Committee. These collaborations have given students and faculty access to unique Native Hawaiian cultural heritage and scientific research study areas. Several have agreed to host student internship programs so that Kaua’i CC students can work directly with GIS professionals on applied problem –solving.

Instructors at Kaua’i CC are increasingly using geospatial sciences to supplement their curriculum. Examples include stream water monitoring for sustainability, geodatabase development for agriculture, story mapping for Hawaiian studies and environmental observations for Philosophy.

Another outcome of this project is the successful outreach to the local K-12 community. The faculty and students of the GIS program often work with visiting elementary and middle school groups, engaging students in geospatial activities like the AR sandbox, geocaching, orienteering and locational scavenger hunt activities. The growing popularity resulted in a successful GIS offering at the summer 2017 Kids College event. As a direct result of this grant, two of the local high schools have requested GIS classes for Early College. This is proof that the outreach and marketing of this important STEM field is reaching the community. This is an important pipeline that will only strengthen the GIS program at Kauai CC.
